trans-unit.source: Line of business application Phase 1 | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Line of business application Phase 1 | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Create the virtual network and other Azure infrastructure elements in Phase 1 of the line of business application in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Create the virtual network and other Azure infrastructure elements in Phase 1 of the line of business application in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Line of Business Application Workload Phase 1: Configure Azure
trans-unit.target: Line of Business Application Workload Phase 1: Configure Azure

trans-unit.source: In this phase of deploying an intranet-only, high-availability line of business application in Azure infrastructure services, you build out the Azure networking and storage infrastructure.
trans-unit.target: In this phase of deploying an intranet-only, high-availability line of business application in Azure infrastructure services, you build out the Azure networking and storage infrastructure.

trans-unit.source: You must complete this phase before moving on to <link><linkText>Phase 2</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: You must complete this phase before moving on to <link><linkText>Phase 2</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: See <link><linkText>Deploy a High-Availability Line of Business Application in Azure</linkText><title></title></link> for all of the phases.
trans-unit.target: See <link><linkText>Deploy a High-Availability Line of Business Application in Azure</linkText><title></title></link> for all of the phases.

trans-unit.source: Azure must be provisioned with these basic network components:
trans-unit.target: Azure must be provisioned with these basic network components:

trans-unit.source: A cross-premises virtual network with one subnet for hosting the Azure virtual machines
trans-unit.target: A cross-premises virtual network with one subnet for hosting the Azure virtual machines

trans-unit.source: Two Azure storage accounts to store VHD disk images and extra data disks
trans-unit.target: Two Azure storage accounts to store VHD disk images and extra data disks

trans-unit.source: Three availability sets
trans-unit.target: Three availability sets

trans-unit.source: Before you begin
trans-unit.target: Before you begin

trans-unit.source: Before you begin configuring Azure components, fill in the following tables.
trans-unit.target: Before you begin configuring Azure components, fill in the following tables.

trans-unit.source: To assist you in the procedures for configuring Azure, print this section and write down the needed information or copy this section to a document and fill it in.
trans-unit.target: To assist you in the procedures for configuring Azure, print this section and write down the needed information or copy this section to a document and fill it in.

trans-unit.source: For the settings of the virtual network (VNet), fill in Table V.
trans-unit.target: For the settings of the virtual network (VNet), fill in Table V.

trans-unit.source: Item
trans-unit.target: Item

trans-unit.source: Configuration element
trans-unit.target: Configuration element

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: Value
trans-unit.target: Value

trans-unit.source: | VNet name | A name to assign to the Azure Virtual Network (example SPFarmNet).
trans-unit.target: | VNet name | A name to assign to the Azure Virtual Network (example SPFarmNet).

trans-unit.source: | VNet location | The Azure datacenter that will contain the virtual network.
trans-unit.target: | VNet location | The Azure datacenter that will contain the virtual network.

trans-unit.source: | Local network name | A name to assign to your organization network.
trans-unit.target: | Local network name | A name to assign to your organization network.

trans-unit.source: | VPN device IP address | The public IPv4 address of your VPN device's interface on the Internet.
trans-unit.target: | VPN device IP address | The public IPv4 address of your VPN device's interface on the Internet.

trans-unit.source: Work with your IT department to determine this address.
trans-unit.target: Work with your IT department to determine this address.

trans-unit.source: | VNet address space | The address space (defined in a single private address prefix) for the virtual network.
trans-unit.target: | VNet address space | The address space (defined in a single private address prefix) for the virtual network.

trans-unit.source: Work with your IT department to determine this address space.
trans-unit.target: Work with your IT department to determine this address space.

trans-unit.source: | The first DNS server for the virtual network | The fourth possible IP address for the address space of the second subnet of the virtual network (see Table S).
trans-unit.target: | The first DNS server for the virtual network | The fourth possible IP address for the address space of the second subnet of the virtual network (see Table S).

trans-unit.source: Work with your IT department to determine this address.
trans-unit.target: Work with your IT department to determine this address.

trans-unit.source: | The second DNS server for the virtual network | The fifth possible IP address for the address space of the second subnet of the virtual network (see Table S).
trans-unit.target: | The second DNS server for the virtual network | The fifth possible IP address for the address space of the second subnet of the virtual network (see Table S).

trans-unit.source: Work with your IT department to determine this address.
trans-unit.target: Work with your IT department to determine this address.

trans-unit.source: | IPsec shared key | A 128-character random, alphanumeric string that will be used to authenticate both sides of the site-to-site VPN connection.
trans-unit.target: | IPsec shared key | A 128-character random, alphanumeric string that will be used to authenticate both sides of the site-to-site VPN connection.

trans-unit.source: Work with your IT or security department to determine this key value.
trans-unit.target: Work with your IT or security department to determine this key value.

trans-unit.source: Table V: Cross-premises virtual network configuration
trans-unit.target: Table V: Cross-premises virtual network configuration

trans-unit.source: Fill in Table S for the subnet of this solution.
trans-unit.target: Fill in Table S for the subnet of this solution.

trans-unit.source: For the first subnet, determine a 29-bit address space (with a /29 prefix length) for the Azure gateway subnet.
trans-unit.target: For the first subnet, determine a 29-bit address space (with a /29 prefix length) for the Azure gateway subnet.

trans-unit.source: For the second subnet, specify a friendly name, a single IP address space based on the Virtual Network address space, and a descriptive purpose.
trans-unit.target: For the second subnet, specify a friendly name, a single IP address space based on the Virtual Network address space, and a descriptive purpose.

trans-unit.source: Work with your IT department to determine these address spaces from the virtual network address space.
trans-unit.target: Work with your IT department to determine these address spaces from the virtual network address space.

trans-unit.source: Both address spaces should be in Classless Interdomain Routing (CIDR) format, also known as network prefix format.
trans-unit.target: Both address spaces should be in Classless Interdomain Routing (CIDR) format, also known as network prefix format.

trans-unit.source: An example is 10.24.64.0/20.
trans-unit.target: An example is 10.24.64.0/20.

trans-unit.source: Item
trans-unit.target: Item

trans-unit.source: Subnet name
trans-unit.target: Subnet name

trans-unit.source: Subnet address space
trans-unit.target: Subnet address space

trans-unit.source: Purpose
trans-unit.target: Purpose

trans-unit.source: | Gateway subnet | _________________________ | The subnet used by the Azure gateway virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: | Gateway subnet | _________________________ | The subnet used by the Azure gateway virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: Table S: Subnets in the virtual network
trans-unit.target: Table S: Subnets in the virtual network

trans-unit.source: This pre-defined architecture uses a single subnet for simplicity.
trans-unit.target: This pre-defined architecture uses a single subnet for simplicity.

trans-unit.source: If you want to overlay a set of traffic filters to emulate subnet isolation, you can use Azure <link><linkText>Network Security Groups</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you want to overlay a set of traffic filters to emulate subnet isolation, you can use Azure <link><linkText>Network Security Groups</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: For the two on-premises DNS servers that you want to use when initially setting up the domain controllers in your virtual network, fill in Table D. Give each DNS server a friendly name and a single IP address.
trans-unit.target: For the two on-premises DNS servers that you want to use when initially setting up the domain controllers in your virtual network, fill in Table D. Give each DNS server a friendly name and a single IP address.

trans-unit.source: This friendly name does not need to match the host name or computer name of the DNS server.
trans-unit.target: This friendly name does not need to match the host name or computer name of the DNS server.

trans-unit.source: Note that two blank entries are listed, but you can add more.
trans-unit.target: Note that two blank entries are listed, but you can add more.

trans-unit.source: Work with your IT department to determine this list.
trans-unit.target: Work with your IT department to determine this list.

trans-unit.source: Item
trans-unit.target: Item

trans-unit.source: DNS server friendly name
trans-unit.target: DNS server friendly name

trans-unit.source: DNS server IP address
trans-unit.target: DNS server IP address

trans-unit.source: Table D: On-premises DNS servers
trans-unit.target: Table D: On-premises DNS servers

trans-unit.source: To route packets from the Azure virtual network to your organization network across the site-to-site VPN connection, you must configure the virtual network with a local network that contains a list of the address spaces (in CIDR notation) for all of the reachable locations on your organization's on-premises network.
trans-unit.target: To route packets from the Azure virtual network to your organization network across the site-to-site VPN connection, you must configure the virtual network with a local network that contains a list of the address spaces (in CIDR notation) for all of the reachable locations on your organization's on-premises network.

trans-unit.source: The list of address spaces that define your local network must be unique and must not overlap with the address space used for other virtual networks or other local networks.
trans-unit.target: The list of address spaces that define your local network must be unique and must not overlap with the address space used for other virtual networks or other local networks.

trans-unit.source: For the set of local network address spaces, fill in Table L. Note that three blank entries are listed but you will typically need more.
trans-unit.target: For the set of local network address spaces, fill in Table L. Note that three blank entries are listed but you will typically need more.

trans-unit.source: Work with your IT department to determine this list of address spaces.
trans-unit.target: Work with your IT department to determine this list of address spaces.

trans-unit.source: Item
trans-unit.target: Item

trans-unit.source: Local network address space
trans-unit.target: Local network address space

trans-unit.source: Table L: Address prefixes for the local network
trans-unit.target: Table L: Address prefixes for the local network

trans-unit.source: Next, you need to have Azure PowerShell version 0.9.5 or later installed.
trans-unit.target: Next, you need to have Azure PowerShell version 0.9.5 or later installed.

trans-unit.source: To check your version of Azure PowerShell, run this command.
trans-unit.target: To check your version of Azure PowerShell, run this command.

trans-unit.source: If you need to install the latest version of Azure PowerShell, use Control Panel-Programs and Features to remove the current version.
trans-unit.target: If you need to install the latest version of Azure PowerShell, use Control Panel-Programs and Features to remove the current version.

trans-unit.source: Then, use the instructions in <link><linkText>How to install and configure Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title></link> to install Azure PowerShell on your local computer.
trans-unit.target: Then, use the instructions in <link><linkText>How to install and configure Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title></link> to install Azure PowerShell on your local computer.

trans-unit.source: Open an Azure PowerShell prompt.
trans-unit.target: Open an Azure PowerShell prompt.

trans-unit.source: First, select the correct Azure subscription with these commands. Replace everything within the quotes, including the < and > characters, with the correct names.
trans-unit.target: First, select the correct Azure subscription with these commands. Replace everything within the quotes, including the < and > characters, with the correct names.

trans-unit.source: You can get the subscription name from the SubscriptionName property of the output of the Get-AzureSubscription command.
trans-unit.target: You can get the subscription name from the SubscriptionName property of the output of the Get-AzureSubscription command.

trans-unit.source: Next, switch Azure PowerShell into Resource Manager mode with this command.
trans-unit.target: Next, switch Azure PowerShell into Resource Manager mode with this command.

trans-unit.source: Next, create a new resource group for your line of business application.
trans-unit.target: Next, create a new resource group for your line of business application.

trans-unit.source: To determine a unique resource group name, use this command to list your existing resource groups.
trans-unit.target: To determine a unique resource group name, use this command to list your existing resource groups.

trans-unit.source: To list the Azure locations where you can create Resource Manager-based virtual machines, use these commands.
trans-unit.target: To list the Azure locations where you can create Resource Manager-based virtual machines, use these commands.

trans-unit.source: Create your new resource group with these commands.
trans-unit.target: Create your new resource group with these commands.

trans-unit.source: Resource Manager-based virtual machines require a Resource Manager-based storage account.
trans-unit.target: Resource Manager-based virtual machines require a Resource Manager-based storage account.

trans-unit.source: Item
trans-unit.target: Item

trans-unit.source: Storage account name
trans-unit.target: Storage account name

trans-unit.source: Purpose
trans-unit.target: Purpose

trans-unit.source: | _______________________ | The premium storage account used by the SQL server virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: | _______________________ | The premium storage account used by the SQL server virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: | _______________________ | The standard storage account used by all the other virtual machines in the workload.
trans-unit.target: | _______________________ | The standard storage account used by all the other virtual machines in the workload.

trans-unit.source: Table ST: Storage accounts
trans-unit.target: Table ST: Storage accounts

trans-unit.source: You will need these names when you create the virtual machines in phases 2, 3, and 4.
trans-unit.target: You will need these names when you create the virtual machines in phases 2, 3, and 4.

trans-unit.source: You must pick a globally unique name for each storage account that contains only lowercase letters and numbers.
trans-unit.target: You must pick a globally unique name for each storage account that contains only lowercase letters and numbers.

trans-unit.source: You can use this command to list the existing storage accounts.
trans-unit.target: You can use this command to list the existing storage accounts.

trans-unit.source: To test whether a chosen storage account name is globally unique, you need to run the Test-AzureName command in the Azure Service Management mode of PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: To test whether a chosen storage account name is globally unique, you need to run the Test-AzureName command in the Azure Service Management mode of PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Use these commands.
trans-unit.target: Use these commands.

trans-unit.source: If the Test-AzureName command displays False, your proposed name is unique.
trans-unit.target: If the Test-AzureName command displays False, your proposed name is unique.

trans-unit.source: When you have determined a unique name for both storage accounts, update table ST, and then switch Azure PowerShell back to Resource Manager mode with this command.
trans-unit.target: When you have determined a unique name for both storage accounts, update table ST, and then switch Azure PowerShell back to Resource Manager mode with this command.

trans-unit.source: To create the first storage account, run these commands.
trans-unit.target: To create the first storage account, run these commands.

trans-unit.source: To create the second storage account, run these commands.
trans-unit.target: To create the second storage account, run these commands.

trans-unit.source: Next, you create the Azure Virtual Network that will host your line of business application.
trans-unit.target: Next, you create the Azure Virtual Network that will host your line of business application.

trans-unit.source: Next, use these commands to create the gateways for the site-to-site VPN connection.
trans-unit.target: Next, use these commands to create the gateways for the site-to-site VPN connection.

trans-unit.source: Next, configure on-premises VPN device to connect to the Azure VPN gateway.
trans-unit.target: Next, configure on-premises VPN device to connect to the Azure VPN gateway.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>Configure your VPN device</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>Configure your VPN device</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: To configure your on-premises VPN device, you will need the following:
trans-unit.target: To configure your on-premises VPN device, you will need the following:

trans-unit.source: The public IPv4 address of the Azure VPN gateway for your virtual network (from the display of the Get-AzurePublicIpAddress -Name $publicGatewayVipName -ResourceGroupName $rgName command)
trans-unit.target: The public IPv4 address of the Azure VPN gateway for your virtual network (from the display of the Get-AzurePublicIpAddress -Name $publicGatewayVipName -ResourceGroupName $rgName command)

trans-unit.source: The IPsec pre-shared key for the site-to-site VPN connection (Table V- Item 8 – Value column)
trans-unit.target: The IPsec pre-shared key for the site-to-site VPN connection (Table V- Item 8 – Value column)

trans-unit.source: Next, ensure that the address space of the virtual network is reachable from your on-premises network.
trans-unit.target: Next, ensure that the address space of the virtual network is reachable from your on-premises network.

trans-unit.source: This is usually done by adding a route corresponding to the virtual network address space to your VPN device and then advertising that route to the rest of the routing infrastructure of your organization network.
trans-unit.target: This is usually done by adding a route corresponding to the virtual network address space to your VPN device and then advertising that route to the rest of the routing infrastructure of your organization network.

trans-unit.source: Work with your IT department to determine how to do this.
trans-unit.target: Work with your IT department to determine how to do this.

trans-unit.source: Next, define the names of three availability sets.
trans-unit.target: Next, define the names of three availability sets.

trans-unit.source: Fill out Table A.
trans-unit.target: Fill out Table A.

trans-unit.source: Item
trans-unit.target: Item

trans-unit.source: Purpose
trans-unit.target: Purpose

trans-unit.source: Availability set name
trans-unit.target: Availability set name

trans-unit.source: | Domain controllers | _______________________
trans-unit.target: | Domain controllers | _______________________

trans-unit.source: | SQL servers | _______________________
trans-unit.target: | SQL servers | _______________________

trans-unit.source: | Web servers | _______________________
trans-unit.target: | Web servers | _______________________

trans-unit.source: Table A: Availability set names
trans-unit.target: Table A: Availability set names

trans-unit.source: You will need these names when you create the virtual machines in phases 2, 3, and 4.
trans-unit.target: You will need these names when you create the virtual machines in phases 2, 3, and 4.

trans-unit.source: Create these new availability sets with these Azure PowerShell commands.
trans-unit.target: Create these new availability sets with these Azure PowerShell commands.

trans-unit.source: This is the configuration resulting from the successful completion of this phase.
trans-unit.target: This is the configuration resulting from the successful completion of this phase.

trans-unit.source: Next step
trans-unit.target: Next step

trans-unit.source: To continue with the configuration of this workload, go to <link><linkText>Phase 2: Configure Domain Controllers</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To continue with the configuration of this workload, go to <link><linkText>Phase 2: Configure Domain Controllers</linkText><title></title></link>.
